instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: SOLVED: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board with quite of heavy corrosion on this area

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4V3
<SIGNAL>PP5VS0_FET</SIGNAL>- 0 -2.3V pulsing
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>- 0 -1.6V pulsing
<SIGNAL>CHRG_VREFQ</SIGNAL> - 3.33V - 0V pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.08V

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHRG_VDD</SIGNAL> - 5.12V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> - 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.56 - 12.33V power cycles

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.40V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_ENABLE</SIGNAL> - 3.42V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0 - 1.2V pulsing

Also, although the board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board view doesn't seem to match exactly to the board. For example, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is not on the top corner. Does anyone have the matching board view for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A?

threads.title: SOLVED: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
The 4924 boardview I have, has the SPI chip placed in the center of the top side.
I didn't see any other boardview for 4924...

Does your board turn on in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: SOLVED: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message: It doesn't. When left on the side for a while and I apply the charger it pulls 0.26A for a couple sec and drops back to 0.01A

threads.title: SOLVED: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Do you get pulse at all big coils?
Check for short on coils and secondary power rails; Misc Power supplies and Power FETs pages.

Also check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: SOLVED: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Found the issue, thank you for your time. 


Initially, I was looking at these coils which had No Short on big coils or big caps
Pulse on L7520, L7430, L7310/20, L7630

Non-pulsing coils 
L7560 - 3.3V
L7130 - 12.5V

When I measured pin 7 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> it starts pulling 0.17A. Seems like the internal resistance of the multimeter spun it up. 
I could feel the CPU was getting slightly warm, but no USB activity (only blinks ones) nor any screen. Also no more pulsing coils. 

Voltages on the big coils seem fine.

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
Pin 7 - 0.26V
Pin 3 - 0.3 -0.18V discharging

Then I decided to lift up <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, and as I thought it had corroded pin 9 PPV3V42-G3H, which must be the reason for pulsing voltages as it doesn't get stable voltage. 


Thanks for your assistance.
